newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Russian MinFins firm in more active trade.
newsitem.headline: Russian MinFins firm in more active trade.

text.p: Prices of Russian MinFin bonds firmed in lively arbitrage trading and dealers said Russia' intention to repay some tsarist debts had stimulated buying among foreign operators.
"The market is firmer today, buying interest is seen both among Russian and Western operators," National Reserve Bank dealer Andrei Ivanov-Golitsyn said.
He added arbitrage trading was mainly seen today, with banks selling one tranche and buying another.
Dealers said the third, fourth and sixth tranches were traded most actively. They were meeting resistance at 84.25, 61.25 and 49.15 respectively.
Dealers said trading was more active compared with the beginning of the week.
"News that Russia will pay some of the tsarist debts provoked some demand from London operators. The market has become lively after a pause," Sberbank dealer Pavel Sool said.

Russian and French prime ministers Viktor Chernomyrdin and Alain Juppe reached the debt deal on Tuesday at Paris talks which required Moscow to pay $400 million to holders of the bonds, which were issued before the 1917 Bolshevik revolution.
